But these technique reqires more effort. So other PR is needed in the future.

@kumarvishal09 I agree with your points. 
1). Let's move all sort logic into a SortStep including the merge part then pass the row to MDKeyGenStep. Then we can change the implementation of it without changing interface. 
2). We can do the similar way as Spark. In spark, there are [`ExternalSorter`](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/util/collection/ExternalSorter.scala) and [`UnsafeInMemorySorter`](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/core/src/main/java/org/apache/spark/util/collection/unsafe/sort/UnsafeInMemorySorter.java) for safe and unsafe version. `ExternalSorter` internally uses [`TimSort`](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/core/src/main/java/org/apache/spark/util/collection/TimSort.java), you  can see descrption of `sort` function about the space usage:

```
In the worst case, this sort requires
 temporary storage space for n/2 object references; in the best case,
  it requires only a small constant amount of space.
```

And for `UnsafeInMemorySorter`, it is sorting using a key prefix to approve CPU cache efficiency:

```
/**
 * Sorts records using an AlphaSort-style key-prefix sort. This sort stores pointers to records
 * alongside a user-defined prefix of the record's sorting key. When the underlying sort algorithm
 * compares records, it will first compare the stored key prefixes; if the prefixes are not equal,
 * then we do not need to traverse the record pointers to compare the actual records. Avoiding these
 * random memory accesses improves cache hit rates.
 */
```

Is it ok I do the 1) in this PR and leave 2) for future PR?

Can you explain : adding the dummy option for not doing compression, can bring what kinds of benefit?
LGTM
LGTM

This PR has two benefits:
1. Modify the compressor inteface to make it easier to add new compressors, like adding no compression option, and other compressor like lz4, gzip, etc. Based on this PR, developer can add lz4 compressor in the future, which decompression speed is faster than snappy. I found a compression benchmark [here](https://github.com/ning/jvm-compressor-benchmark/wiki)
2. If the query is CPU bound but not IO bound, using no compression will be faster because decompress time is saved.

Can you separate out the creation of `dataHandler` into a Factory class,  and use that factory in `DataWriterProcessorStepImpl`. The logic will be cleaner

Suggest to modify the implementation name to `PipelinedWriterProcessorStepImpl` since it is assuming last step is a merge sort step and using producer-consumer to write in a pipelined manner.
In future, if sort step implements external sort (in memory sort), we could add a parallel write implementation for this step. (ParallelWriterProcessorStepImpl). So at that time, the factory can be reused but it is called in a new thread.
Verified OK, LGTM.

@jackylk  This data writer step is not assuming merge sort with producer-consumer. Even we did not integrate producer-consumer for merge sort in our code. This step can receive sorted data from any type of step(even for in memory sort step.)
The producer-consumer present in CarbonFactHandler implementation is for parallel processing the block after it receives blocklet size of rows.

please rebase and request the commits.
fix jira issue carbondata-339,  align storePath name for the  generateGlobalDictionary function in GlobalDictionaryUtil.scala

I prefer the new layout of carbondata files as following.

```
storelocation
    |__database_0
            |__table_0
                    |__metadata
                    |__partition_0
                            |__segment_0
                                    |__fact_0
                                    |__index_0
                                    |__......
```

Segment manager can include fact, index and so on. 
After this, we can extend carbon table by basing segment level.
Please modify the PR title, like `[CARBONDATA-339] description of the PR`
@QiangCai I prefer not to modify the folder structure of Carbon, otherwise new version will not be backward compatible.

@ravipesala @QiangCai @JihongMA @chenliang613

@JihongMA  I have added a function in CarbonTableInputFormat to select the index to be used.
see https://github.com/apache/incubator-carbondata/pull/208/files#diff-1cb4c4e1751ea76cd7dcc596cde82abaR156

Driver side query optimizer or in rdd.getPartition can call this function to select index. The selected index name will be set in the configuration object, and CarbonTableInputFormat will use the selected index to do file pruning in getSplit

Is this enough?

I have removed ColumnarInputFormat but keep a TableInputFormat only:
1. TableInputFormat contains multiple segments.
2. In getSplit function, it loop for all segments and delegate the getSplit to each segment. Segment can make use of the index to do file pruning.
3. In createRecordReader function, it create the record reader according to the format type in the split.
There is one compilation error in `CarbonDataProcessorUtil` because of other merged PR
